awd_titl_txt: Elements: Development of Assumption-Free Parallel Data Curing Service for Robust Machine Learning and Statistical Predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
Large, incomplete datasets create major challenges for statistical prediction in research.  This project will develop a data curing service that is able to manage large, incomplete, and diverse datasets, and would provide uncertainty measures for the cured data.  The project identifies and collaborates with several communities where this data service is central to scientific research, including civil engineering, building science, urban energy, and social science. 

The effort creates a parallel data curing service, provides uncertainty measures for the cured data, and develops supplementary imputing algorithms.  The team develops a data curing platform with imputation for incomplete, heterogeneous data; robust machine learning (ML) and statistical predictions would be established by developing an easy-to-use, general-purpose, large data-friendly imputation program.  The focus is on a novel combination of three established imputation methods: two-level finite mixture model-based imputation (FMMI), fractional hot deck imputation (FHDI), and Gaussian mixture model-based imputation (GMMI), for which parallel implementations in R would also be provided. 

This award by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly funded by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
High-quality data is the vital foundation for the advanced machine learning (ML) and statistical inference. Thud, quality control of data is an indispensable pillar under the artificial intelligence- and data-driven innovations in broad science and engineering. Missing data issue is found in every corner of engineering and scientific research process due to many reasons including human errors, unexpected malfunctions of sensors or other data acquisition systems and so on. Mishandling of incomplete data may result in biased inference or conclusions. However, curing the general missing data is not trivial task, and there have been a plethora of theoretical and computational efforts, called as “imputation” theory and methods.

The use of advanced imputation methods for engineering and scientific research is difficult since they often require in-depth statistical knowledge and complex assumptions about the data distributions. Furthermore, it is difficult to find large/big data-oriented imputation methods while the state-of-the-art ML and data-driven research need to handle large incomplete data.

This NSF CSSI project was created to develop assumption-free, general-purpose incomplete data curing software and the supporting theories by forming a strong team of theoretical statistics and computational science and engineering. The developed software can cure general incomplete data without requiring complex assumptions about statistics, but it only requires the incomplete data set as it is. Moreover, this project developed the ultra data-oriented data curing software that can cure ultra data (i.e., concurrently large instances “big-n” and high dimensionality “big-p”) up to millions of instances and tens of thousands of variables at the same time (Fig. 1). To the best of PIs’ knowledge, this is the first ultra incomplete data curing software available in the world. The developed software is named as UP-FHDI (Ultra data-oriented Parallel Fractional Hot Deck Imputation).

During this project, PIs conducted diverse validations with practically important data sets spanning broad science and engineering. The positive impact of the UP-FHDI on the subsequent ML method’s accuracy has been confirmed. Also, PIs confirmed the relatively stable performance compared to the state-of-the-art ML-based imputation methods (e.g., generative adversarial imputation nets, Yoon et al. 2018). Results are summarized in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3.  The developed data curing software holds the positive impacts on subsequent ML and statistical inferences. During this project PIs confirmed the positive impact with a variety of ML methods and advanced statistical methods (Fig. 4).

Another noteworthy accomplishment of the UP-FHDI is that it provides uncertainty measures to the software user after the data curing task. Missing data curing is not deterministic process. Thus, providing the uncertainty behind the cured data set is important for the researcher for their uncertainty-aware decision making and deriving scientific conclusions. PIs developed and implement the linearized variance estimation technique specialized for the ultra incomplete data curing process. Methods and results are presented in PIs’ work [Yicheng et al. 2023, IEEE TKDE].

PIs of this project strongly believe that the developed assumption-free general-purpose data curing software will push the boundary of data-driven innovations in broad science and engineering. Researchers in all disciplines of engineering, science, and beyond begin to leverage the data curing software. Fig. 5 summarizes the global impacts and expanding user groups of the software. As of February 2024, the global download hit more than 40,000 according to the global statistical software outlet CRAN. For broader impacts of this project, all the developed software, source codes, and test data sets are shared via IEEE DataPort.  This project’s outcomes will help accelerate the data-driven innovations and discoveries in a wide spectrum of science and engineering.

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2024
Modified by: In Ho Cho
